theme: God's mercy extends beyond Israel - prophet's resistance vs God's compassion
messiahProfile: Greater prophet who obeys unto death and rejoices in mercy to enemies
overview: Jonah reveals God's heart for all nations through a reluctant prophet who resents God's compassion for Nineveh.

narrative.storyPanels: Panel 1: Jonah flees to Tarshish. Panel 2: Storm threatens ship. Panel 3: Jonah cast into sea. Panel 4: Fish swallows Jonah
narrative.pattern: Can't run from God - His purposes will be accomplished even through our rebellion
narrative.messiahLink: Jonah in fish 3 days/nights = Jesus in tomb (Matt 12:39-40). But Jesus went willingly
narrative.notes: Pagan sailors fear God more than God's prophet does. Irony throughout

narrative.storyPanels: Panel 1: Jonah angry at God's mercy. Panel 2: Jonah quotes Exodus 34:6 in anger. Panel 3: Plant grows, Jonah happy. Panel 4: Plant dies, Jonah furious
narrative.pattern: We love God's mercy for us, resent it for enemies. God's question: Should I not have compassion?
narrative.messiahLink: Jesus is the greater Jonah who rejoices in showing mercy to enemies, dies for them
narrative.notes: Book ends with God's unanswered question hanging in the air

expository.tension: Jonah knows God is gracious (Ex 34:6-7) but resents Him showing grace to enemies
expository.structure: v.1-4 (Jonah's anger), v.5-8 (Plant lesson), v.9-11 (God's question)
expository.messiahProfile: God who has compassion on 120,000 who don't know right from left
expository.messiahLink: Jesus weeps over Jerusalem, dies for enemies - He IS God's compassion embodied
expository.notes: Jonah quotes Exodus 34:6 as a COMPLAINT. We do the same - we want grace for us, judgment for them
